content.title: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
content.summary: Most common cause of peripheral vertigo characterized by brief episodes of spinning sensation triggered by changes in head position, caused by displaced otoconia in the semicircular canals
key_points: Most common cause of vertigo (17-42% of cases)
Caused by otoconia (calcium carbonate crystals) dislodged into semicircular canals
Posterior canal affected in 80-90% of cases
Dix-Hallpike test is diagnostic (upbeat torsional nystagmus)
Epley maneuver is first-line treatment (80-90% success rate)
Episodes typically last <60 seconds with position change
No hearing loss or tinnitus (distinguishes from Meniere's)

statement.text: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is the most common cause of peripheral vertigo, characterized by brief episodes of spinning sensation triggered by changes in head position relative to gravity. It results from dislodged otoconia (calcium carbonate crystals) in the semicircular canals, most commonly the posterior canal. Diagnosis is confirmed by the Dix-Hallpike maneuver demonstrating characteristic geotropic nystagmus, and treatment with canalith repositioning procedures (Epley maneuver) achieves resolution in 80-90% of cases.
statement.formal: BPPV = Positional vertigo (<60s) + Dix-Hallpike positive (upbeat torsional nystagmus) + No hearing loss/tinnitus

explanation.intuition: Imagine tiny calcium crystals normally attached to a membrane in your inner ear breaking loose and falling into one of the fluid-filled balance canals. When you move your head, these crystals shift with gravity, creating abnormal fluid movement that your brain misinterprets as spinning. The key insight is that BPPV is mechanical - loose crystals in the wrong place - which explains why repositioning maneuvers work so well.
explanation.key_insight: The posterior semicircular canal is most commonly affected because of its anatomical position as the most gravity-dependent canal when upright. The characteristic upbeat-torsional nystagmus on Dix-Hallpike testing reflects the specific orientation of this canal. Treatment success depends on correctly identifying the affected canal and using the appropriate repositioning maneuver.
explanation.technical_details: Otoconia are normally embedded in the otolithic membrane of the utricle and saccule. When dislodged, they can enter the semicircular canals causing either canalithiasis (free-floating in canal) or cupulolithiasis (attached to cupula). The Epley maneuver uses gravity to move otoconia through the posterior canal back into the utricle. Horizontal canal BPPV requires the BBQ roll or Gufoni maneuver instead.

definitions_glossary.benign_paroxysmal_positional_vertigo: Most common peripheral vestibular disorder causing brief vertigo episodes triggered by head position changes
definitions_glossary.otoconia: Calcium carbonate crystals (also called otoliths or canaliths) normally attached to the utricular macula that detect linear acceleration
definitions_glossary.semicircular_canals: Three fluid-filled loops in the inner ear (posterior, anterior, horizontal) that detect rotational head movements
definitions_glossary.canalithiasis: Condition where otoconia are free-floating within a semicircular canal, causing abnormal endolymph movement
definitions_glossary.cupulolithiasis: Condition where otoconia are attached to the cupula of a semicircular canal, making it gravity-sensitive
definitions_glossary.dix_hallpike_maneuver: Diagnostic test where patient is rapidly moved from sitting to supine with head turned 45° and extended, observing for nystagmus
definitions_glossary.epley_maneuver: Canalith repositioning procedure using sequential head positions to move otoconia from posterior canal back to utricle
definitions_glossary.geotropic_nystagmus: Nystagmus that beats toward the ground (earth) when the head is turned to the affected side
definitions_glossary.apogeotropic_nystagmus: Nystagmus that beats away from the ground, seen in cupulolithiasis or horizontal canal BPPV
definitions_glossary.vestibular_neuritis: Inflammation of vestibular nerve causing acute prolonged vertigo without hearing loss (differential diagnosis)
definitions_glossary.labyrinthitis: Inner ear inflammation affecting both vestibular and cochlear function (vertigo with hearing loss)
definitions_glossary.utricle: Otolith organ in the vestibule that detects horizontal linear acceleration and head tilt
definitions_glossary.cupula: Gelatinous structure in the ampulla of each semicircular canal that deflects with endolymph flow

pathophysiology.mechanism: Otoconia from the utricle become dislodged (often due to head trauma, aging, or idiopathic causes) and migrate into one of the semicircular canals. When the head position changes relative to gravity, the dense otoconia move through the endolymph, creating abnormal fluid dynamics that deflect the cupula and stimulate vestibular hair cells. This sends false rotational signals to the brain, perceived as vertigo.
cellular_events: Otoconia dislodge from utricular macula (trauma, degeneration, or spontaneous)
Crystals migrate into semicircular canal (usually posterior due to anatomy)
Head position change causes otoconia to move with gravity
Moving otoconia create endolymph flow (canalithiasis) or cupula weight (cupulolithiasis)
Cupula deflection triggers vestibular hair cell firing
Asymmetric vestibular signals create vertigo and nystagmus
VOR mismatch causes oscillopsia and imbalance
Symptoms resolve when otoconia settle (typically <60 seconds)

canal_variants.posterior_canal: 80-90% of cases; Dix-Hallpike positive; Epley maneuver treatment
canal_variants.horizontal_canal: 5-15% of cases; roll test positive; BBQ roll or Gufoni maneuver
canal_variants.anterior_canal: 1-3% of cases; rare due to superior anatomy; Epley or deep head-hanging maneuver

history: Triggered by specific head position changes
Provoked by lying down, rolling over, looking up
examination: Latency of 1-5 seconds before nystagmus onset

nystagmus_characteristics.posterior_canal: Upbeat + torsional (top of eye toward affected ear), geotropic, duration 10-30 seconds
nystagmus_characteristics.horizontal_canal_canalithiasis: Horizontal geotropic, stronger toward affected side
nystagmus_characteristics.horizontal_canal_cupulolithiasis: Horizontal apogeotropic, stronger toward unaffected side
nystagmus_characteristics.anterior_canal: Downbeat + torsional (top of eye away from affected ear)

epley_maneuver.technique: Sequential head positions moving otoconia through canal into utricle

pharmacotherapy.role: Limited - primarily for symptom relief during acute episodes
pharmacotherapy.antihistamines: Meclizine, dimenhydrinate for acute nausea (not routine)
pharmacotherapy.benzodiazepines: Rarely used; may delay vestibular compensation

vestibular_rehabilitation.indication: Persistent symptoms, recurrent BPPV, or residual dizziness after repositioning
vestibular_rehabilitation.components: Habituation exercises, balance training, gaze stabilization

surgical.indication: Refractory BPPV not responding to repositioning (very rare)

definition.@value: Most common peripheral vestibular disorder characterized by brief episodes of vertigo triggered by head position changes, caused by displaced otoconia in the semicircular canals

skos.scopeNote: Includes posterior, horizontal, and anterior canal variants; diagnosis by positional testing; treatment by canalith repositioning maneuvers
skos.example: A 55-year-old woman with sudden vertigo lasting 30 seconds when rolling over in bed, positive Dix-Hallpike with upbeat-torsional nystagmus, resolved after single Epley maneuver

learning_objectives: Explain the pathophysiology of BPPV including otoconia displacement and canal dynamics
Perform and interpret the Dix-Hallpike test for posterior canal BPPV
Distinguish BPPV from other causes of vertigo based on history and examination
Execute the Epley maneuver for treatment of posterior canal BPPV
Recognize horizontal canal BPPV and select appropriate repositioning technique
clinical_pearls: Posterior canal BPPV: upbeat + torsional nystagmus toward affected ear
Horizontal canal BPPV: horizontal nystagmus, stronger on roll test to affected side
BPPV episodes are brief (<60 seconds) - prolonged vertigo suggests vestibular neuritis
No hearing loss in BPPV - hearing loss suggests Meniere's or labyrinthitis
Epley success rate drops if patient has positional restriction post-procedure - evidence is weak
Residual dizziness after successful Epley is common and usually resolves in 1-2 weeks

board_yield.neurology_boards: High - detailed canal variants and repositioning techniques

common_misconceptions: BPPV is caused by inner ear infection (false - it's mechanical displacement of otoconia)
Medications are first-line for BPPV (false - canalith repositioning is first-line)
A negative Dix-Hallpike excludes BPPV (false - horizontal canal BPPV requires roll test)
BPPV always resolves after one Epley maneuver (false - may require multiple treatments)

skos:related.skos:note: Differential diagnosis - prolonged vertigo without hearing loss
Differential diagnosis - vertigo with hearing loss and tinnitus
